Name: Flin Flon Reminder
What happened?: The independent Flin Flon Reminder reduced publication from a daily to three times a week as of April 29th 2005. In August 2015, the paper started publishing twice a week.

Name: Langley Times
What happened?: In early July 2009, the Langley Times, a Black Press community newspaper, dropped its publication schedule from three days to two.

Name: Penticton Western Daily News
What happened?: The Penticton Western Daily News ceased daily publication in 2011. Black Press retains its community newspaper in Penticton, which is named the Penticton Western News.

Name: Surrey Leader Daily
What happened?: The Surrey Leader Daily, a free daily newspaper owned by Black Press, ceased publishing in 2011. Black Press still has a community newspaper, the Surrey North Delta Leader.

Name: Terrace-Kitimat-Prince Rupert Northern Daily
What happened?: Terrace-Kitimat-Prince Rupert Northern Daily, a free daily newspaper owned by Black Press, ceased publishing in September 2012. This was another free daily newspaper experiment by Black Press. There remains a community newspaper in all three of the communities, as well as a tri-community weekly paper.

Name: Kelownanow.com
What happened?: KelownaNow, an online site, first appeared in 2012.

Name: The Dunnville Chronicle
What happened?: The Dunnville Chronicle was closed by Sun Media in November, 2012, at the same time as the West Niagara News, leaving one newspaper that covers the entire Niagara region.

Name: Barrhaven Independent
What happened?: Barrhaven Independent shifted from a weekly print to web only in the 1st quarter of 2012. However, they relaunched a print version in February 2013, which publishes the first and third Friday of the month.

Name: La Nouvelle
What happened?: La Nouvelle, a Transcontinental community paper, ceased publication in the first quarter of 2012.

Name: Markdale Standard
What happened?: Markdale Standard, a Sun Media community newspaper, ceased publication in the third quarter of 2012.

Name: Infonews.ca
What happened?: The news section of infotel.ca, which  reports on Vernon, Kelowna, Penticton, and Kamloops, launched at the end of 2012.

Name: The Charter
What happened?: In October 2013 TC Media closed Placentia community paper The Charter after 16 years of publishing.

Name: Chronicle Herald - Halifax
What happened?: Halifax Chronicle Herald combined the Sunday and Saturday editions of the paper.

Name: Lindsay Post
What happened?: The Quebecor-owned The Lindsay Post ceased publication in 2013. At the time of closure it appeared twice per week on Tuesdays and Fridays. Back in May 2007, when the paper was owned by Osprey Media, the paper changed its name from The Daily Post to The Lindsay Post to reflect its change from publishing Monday to Friday to Tuesdays and Fridays.

Name: Oakville Beaver
What happened?: In September 2014 the Oakville Beaver, a Metroland newspaper, cancelled its Wednesday edition. The paper now publishes Thursday and Friday only.

Name: Metro London
What happened?: Metro London, a free daily paper launched by Metro Canada on April 4, 2011, closed in late 2014.

Name: Metro Regina
What happened?: In April 2012, Metro Canada launched Metro Regina with a daily print edition, website and mobile apps. It closed in the third quarter of 2014.

Name: Metro Saskatoon
What happened?: In April 2012, Metro Canada launched Metro Saskatoon with a daily print edition, website and mobile apps. It closed in the third quarter of 2014.

Name: Halifax Daily News
What happened?: Halifax Daily News, a paid daily paper owned by Transcontinental, closed in early 2008.

Name: Metro Halifax
What happened?: Metroland launched the free daily newspaper Metro Halifax in early 2008. It replaced Halifax Daily News.

Name: Ottawa RushHour
What happened?: Ottawa RushHour, a free daily paper launched by CanWest, closed in April 2008, after surviving for just over a year.

Name: Calgary RushHour
What happened?: Calgary RushHour, a free daily paper launched by CanWest, closed in April 2008, after surviving for just over a year.

Name: Edmonton RushHour
What happened?: Edmonton RushHour, a free daily paper launched by CanWest, closed in April 2008, after surviving for just over a year.

Name: 24 Heures - Gatineau
What happened?: Quebecor-owned 24 Heures Gatineau-Ottawa, a free daily newspaper, ceased publication on May 9, 2008.

Name: NewsKamloops.com
What happened?: Armchairmayor.com, a blog run by a former mayor and reporter, added news coverage when the Kamloops Daily News closed. On August 2, 2015 it transformed into NewsKamloops.com, adding sections and staff members.

Name: Around the Block
What happened?: Around the Block, a community newspaper that publishes every two months, began publishing in 2008.  It features articles written by local residents, and focuses on several neighbourhoods.

Name: Jasper Booster
What happened?: Jasper Booster, a Sun-owned community newspaper, ceased publishing in March 2009.

Name: Morinville Redwater Town & Country Examiner
What happened?: The Morinville Redwater Town and Country Examiner was born in November 2008 with the merging of the Morinville Mirror and Redwater Tribune. The paper was shuttered several months later, due to financial reasons.

Name: CHCA-TV
What happened?: Red Deer, Alberta, remains one of the largest Canadian cities outside a major metropolitan market to operate without a TV station following the 2009 closure of the local CanWest station.

Name: CKNX-TV
What happened?: CTV did not renew the licence of this local station, so it closed on August 2009.

Name: CKX-TV
What happened?: CKX aired CBC and A Channel programming; CTV decided to close the station when CBC chose not to renew its rebroadcasting agreement.

Name: Nelson Daily News
What happened?: Nelson Daily News' final print run was in July 2010 as new owner Black Press closed them a few weeks after buying them from Glacier Media.

Name: The Daily News
What happened?: Prince Rupert Daily News' final print run was in July 2010 as new owner Black Press closed them a few weeks after buying them from Glacier Media.
Doc:NewspaperCanada: Was in the 2009 Newspaper Canada Paid Daily, not in the 2010 list

Name: Squamish Today
What happened?: Whistler Today was a local free daily that launched by Glacier Media in 2006. It had a different front page from Squamish Today, which allowed it to carry local news. It was closed in 2011.

Name: Whistler Today
What happened?: Squamish Today was a local free daily that launched by Glacier Media in 2006. It had a different front page from Whistler Today, which allowed it to carry local news. It was closed in 2011.

Name: Metro Winnipeg
What happened?: Metro Canada launched Metro London, a free daily paper, on April 4, 2011.

Name: The Saskatoon Express
What happened?: The Saskatoon Express, a new weekly community newspaper, launched in 2011.

Name: Radio West
What happened?: CBC radio started a drive home (afternoon) show, based in Kelowna in 2011.

Name: Saint John Newschasers
What happened?: Saint John Newschasers is an online site which publishes local news via Twitter and Facebook.

Name: Public Eye
What happened?: The Public Eye was an online site that reported politics. It wasn't financially sustainable for Sean Holman, the reporter/publisher/owner, so it was closed in 2011.

Name: LaSalle Silhouette
What happened?: The LaSalle Silhouette was closed in December 2011.

Name: Tecumseh Tribune
What happened?: Tecumseh Tribune ceased publication at the beginning of 2012.

Name: Caledonia Regional News This Week
What happened?: The Caledonia Regional News This Week closed at the beginning of 2012 due to decreasing ad revenue.

Name: News Now
What happened?: Grimsby News Now, a new weekly community newspaper, launches.

Name: The Montreal Mirror
What happened?: "The growing popularity of digital media and communications has irremediably changed the context in which free cultural weeklies operate, bringing about economic challenges which have unfortunately compromised The Mirror's viability." (Marketwire news release)

Name: Calgary Herald
What happened?: The Calgary Herald moved to a weekend edition printed Saturday and will no longer publish on Sundays.

Name: Edmonton Journal
What happened?: The Edmonton Journal cancelled its Sunday edition.

Name: Ottawa Citizen
What happened?: The Ottawa Citizen moved to a weekend edition printed Saturday and will no longer publish on Sundays.

Name: Gazeta (Toronto ed.)
What happened?: Polish newspaper Gazeta (Toronto ed.) dropped to three times a week in 2012, and became a weekly newspaper as of 2014.

Name: Openfile.ca - Calgary
What happened?: Openfile.ca, an online local news site that provided local news in six Canadian cities ceased publication September 28, 2012. It was launched in mid 2010.

Name: Openfile.ca - Halifax
What happened?: Openfile.ca, an online local news site that provided local news in six Canadian cities ceased publication September 28, 2012. It was launched in mid 2010.

Name: Openfile.ca - Montreal
What happened?: Openfile.ca, an online local news site that provided local news in six Canadian cities ceased publication September 28, 2012. It was launched in mid 2010.

Name: Openfile.ca - Ottawa
What happened?: Openfile.ca, an online local news site that provided local news in six Canadian cities ceased publication September 28, 2012. It was launched in mid 2010.

Name: Openfile.ca - Toronto
What happened?: Openfile.ca, an online local news site that provided local news in six Canadian cities ceased publication September 28, 2012. It was launched in mid 2010.

Name: Openfile.ca - Vancouver
What happened?: Openfile.ca, an online local news site that provided local news in six Canadian cities ceased publication September 28, 2012. It was launched in mid 2010.

Name: Amherstburg Echo
What happened?: The Amherstburg Echo, one of the oldest newspapers in Canada, was closed in October, 2012.

Name: Daybreak
What happened?: CBC radio launched a new morning show in Kamloop , in 2012.

Name: Ottawa Capital City News
What happened?: On March 14, 2012, Sun Media launched a weekly newspaper in Ottawa. It closed by the end of the year.

Name: West Niagara News
What happened?: West Niagara News was closed by Sun Media at the end of 2012. It happened at the same time as the Dunnville Chronicle, leaving one newspaper that covers the entire Niagara region.

Name: Guelph Review
What happened?: On March 14, 2012, Sun Media launched a weekly newspaper in Guelph. It closed at the end of 2012.

Name: Kitchener-Waterloo Review (aka K-W Review)
What happened?: On March 14, 2012, Sun Media launched a weekly newspaper in Kitchener-Waterloo. It closed by the end of the year.

Name: Windsor This Week
What happened?: On March 14, 2012, Sun Media launched a weekly newspaper in Windsor. It closed by the end of the year.

Name: Capital City News
What happened?: Sun Media closed the Capital City News, a community newspaper, at the end of 2012.

Name: Leamington Post
What happened?: The Sun-owned Leamington Post was losing money, and was closed at the end of 2012.

Name: The Daily Graphic
Icon: daily paper - paid : to community news
What happened?: The Sun-owned Daily Graphic became a weekly publication from a daily in 2013.

Name: Town Crier - Bayview Mills
What happened?: In May 2013 Multimedia Nova Corp. ceased publication of its Town Crier newspapers in the Greater Toronto Area after filing for bankruptcy. In August 2013 the Town Crier newspaper chain was purchased by a group of former employees with plans to re-launch the paper in September - the Bayview Mills paper was not relaunched.

Name: Town Crier - Beach-South Riverdale
What happened?: In May 2013 Multimedia Nova Corp. ceased publication of its Town Crier newspapers in the Greater Toronto Area after filing for bankruptcy. In August 2013 the Town Crier newspaper chain was purchased by a group of former employees with plans to re-launch the paper in September - the Beach-South Riverdale paper was not relaunched.

Name: Town Crier - Bloor West
What happened?: In May 2013 Multimedia Nova Corp. ceased publication of its Town Crier newspapers in the Greater Toronto Area after filing for bankruptcy. In August 2013 the Town Crier newspaper chain was purchased by a group of former employees with plans to re-launch the paper in September - the Bloor West paper was not relaunched.

Name: Town Crier - MidTown
What happened?: In May 2013 Multimedia Nova Corp. ceased publication of its Town Crier newspapers in the Greater Toronto Area after filing for bankruptcy. In August 2013 the Town Crier newspaper chain was purchased by a group of former employees with plans to re-launch the paper in September - the MidTown paper was not relaunched.

Name: Town Crier - North York
What happened?: In May 2013 Multimedia Nova Corp. ceased publication of its Town Crier newspapers in the Greater Toronto Area after filing for bankruptcy. In August 2013 the Town Crier newspaper chain was purchased by a group of former employees with plans to re-launch the paper in September - the North York paper was not relaunched.

Name: Town Crier - Riverdale-East York
What happened?: In May 2013 Multimedia Nova Corp. ceased publication of its Town Crier newspapers in the Greater Toronto Area after filing for bankruptcy. In August 2013 the Town Crier newspaper chain was purchased by a group of former employees with plans to re-launch the paper in September - the Riverdale-East York paper was not relaunched.

Name: Town Crier - Toronto Today
What happened?: In May 2013 Multimedia Nova Corp. ceased publication of its Town Crier newspapers in the Greater Toronto Area after filing for bankruptcy. In August 2013 the Town Crier newspaper chain was purchased by a group of former employees with plans to re-launch the paper in September - the Toronto Today, which covered downtown Toronto, was not relaunched.

Name: Vaughan Today
What happened?: Multimedia Nova went into receivership. Vaughan Today was closed in May 2013.

Name: CityNews
What happened?: Rogers cancelled its 24-hour CityNews channel on May 30, 2013. The channel was launched in October 2011.

Name: The Midland Free Press
What happened?: In July 2013 Sun Media announced the closure of The Midland Free Press, a weekly publication.

Name: The Lac du Bonnet Leader
What happened?: In July 2013 Sun Media announced the closure of The Lac du Bonnet Leader, a weekly publication.

Name: The Beausejour Review
What happened?: In July 2013 Sun Media announced the closure of The Beausejour Review, a weekly publication.

Name: L’Action Regionale
What happened?: In July 2013 Sun Media announced the closure of L'Action Regionale, a weekly publication.

Name: 24-7 Red Deer
What happened?: 24-7 Red Deer is part of kiboodle.ca, which is a community social media platform. It was launched in summer of 2013.

Name: Le Magazine Saint-Lambert
What happened?: In July 2013 Sun Media announced the closure of Le Magazine Saint-Lambert, a weekly publication in Quebec.

Name: Le Progrès de Bellechasse
What happened?: Sun Media closed the Le Progrès de Bellechasse in July, 2013.

Name: Westbank and District Community Radio
What happened?: Westbank and District Community Radio is a new community radio station that was launched in July, 2013.

Name: Tekawennake News
What happened?: The Tekawennake News, a community newspaper,  closed in July, 2013.

Name: Town Crier - Forest Hill
What happened?: In May 2013 Multimedia Nova Corp. ceased publication of its Town Crier newspapers in the Greater Toronto Area after filing for bankruptcy. In August 2013 the Town Crier newspaper chain was purchased by a group of former employees with plans to re-launch the paper in September - the Forest Hill paper was relaunched and publishes every two weeks.

Name: Town Crier - Leaside-Rosedale
What happened?: In May 2013 Multimedia Nova Corp. ceased publication of its Town Crier newspapers in the Greater Toronto Area after filing for bankruptcy. In August 2013 the Town Crier newspaper chain was purchased by a group of former employees with plans to re-launch the paper in September - the Leaside-Rosedale paper was relaunched, and publishes every two weeks.

Name: Town Crier - North Toronto
What happened?: In May 2013 Multimedia Nova Corp. ceased publication of its Town Crier newspapers in the Greater Toronto Area after filing for bankruptcy. In August 2013 the Town Crier newspaper chain was purchased by a group of former employees with plans to re-launch the paper in September - the North Toronto paper was relaunched and publishes every two weeks.

Name: Amherst Daily News
Icon: daily paper - paid : to community news
What happened?: The Amherst Daily News stopped daily publication and became a weekly newspaper as of Aug. 2, 2013.

Name: 24 Hours - Calgary
What happened?: Sun Media/Quebecor closed the free daily 24 Hours - Calgary paper on August 2nd, 2013.

Name: 24 Hours - Edmonton
What happened?: Sun Media/Quebecor closed the free daily 24 Hours - Edmonton paper on August 2nd, 2013.

Name: 24 Hours - Ottawa
What happened?: Sun Media/Quebecor closed the free daily 24 Hours - Ottawa paper on August 2nd, 2013.

Name: Two Row Times: the Spirit of All Nations.
What happened?: Two Row Times was launched in August 2013 when the Tekawennake News closed.

Name: Crowsnest Pass Promoter
What happened?: The Crowsnest Pass Promoter was closed by Sun Media in August 2013.

Name: Etobicoke Guardian
What happened?: In September, the Etobicoke Guardian, a Metroland community paper, published its final Tuesday edition. It is now distributed once a week on Thursdays.

Name: North York Mirror
What happened?: In September, the North York Mirror published its final Tuesday edition. It is now distributed once a week on Thursdays. The Metroland community paper was previously published twice a week.

Name: Scarborough Mirror
What happened?: In September, the Scarborough Mirror published its final Tuesday edition. It is now distributed once a week on Thursdays. The Metroland community paper was previously published twice a week.

Name: Norfolk News
What happened?: On October 3, 2013, Metroland launched the first edition of the Norfolk News, a weekly newspaper covering the Norfolk County community.

Name: Victoria News Daily
What happened?: The Victoria News Daily ceased daily publication in November 2013. (It is different from the Victoria News, which has always been a community newspaper. )

Name: Abbotsford Times
What happened?: Black Press closed the Abbotsford Times, a community newspaper, at the end of 2013.

Name: Kamloops Daily News
What happened?: Glacier Media Group closed the Kamloops Daily News on Jan. 11, 2014, leaving British Columbia’s 12th largest city without a daily newspaper.

Name: Kamloops This Week
What happened?: In response to the impending closure of the Daily News, Thompson River Publications Partnership Ltd. announced that Kamloops This Week would increase its publication dates to three days per week effective January 17. Kamloops This Week was originally published as a free daily paper until 2011.

Name: Peace Arch News Daily
What happened?: Peace Arch News Daily, a Black Press title, ceased daily publication in March 2014. The community newspaper, called Peace Arch News, remains in circulation.

Name: The Sarnia Journal
What happened?: The Sarnia Journal, a community paper, was launched in March of 2014 by three local business people.

Name: Vernon Morning Star Daily
What happened?: The Black Press title, Vernon Morning Star Daily, ceased daily publication in March 2014. The community newspaper, called Vernon Morning Star, remains in circulation.

Name: Nanaimo News Bulletin Daily
What happened?: The Black Press title, Nanaimo News Bulletin Daily ceased daily publication March, 2014. The community newspaper, Nanaimo News Bulletin, remains in publication.

Name: Anishinabek News
What happened?: Anishinabek News, a monthly paper that covers First Nations issues, ceased printing hard copies and moved online as of the April 2014 issue.

Name: Chronicle Herald - Nova Scotia
What happened?: In Nova Scotia, the Chronicle Herald launched a new Cape Breton edition of the paper at the end of March 2014.

Name: Cape Breton Star
What happened?: The Cape Breton Star is a new community newspaper launched by independently-owned Chronicle Herald in May 2014.

Name: TO Night
What happened?: In 2013, the daily TO Night , began appearing  twice a week.  It then closed down entirely in 2014.

Name: Halifax Examiner
What happened?: The Halifax-Examiner, a subscriber-funded online investigative news site, was launched in June 2014.

Name: The Grid
What happened?: The Star Media Group's community newspaper The Grid  closed in July 2014.

Name: Voyage North
What happened?: Locally produced Voyage North, the CBC radio drive-home show in Thunder Bay, aired its last show on Aug. 11, 2014 and was replaced with a drive-home show produced from Sudbury, Ontario, more than 1,000 kilometres away.

Name: Here Magazine
What happened?: Originally an independent alternative weekly, Here Magazine closed in August 2014.

Name: L’Écho de Victoriaville
What happened?: L’Écho de Victoriaville, a Quebecor publication, competed with Transcontinental's La Nouvelle Union. It was launched in 2012 and closed in September 2014.

Name: Châteauguay Express
What happened?: Châteauguay Express, launched by Transcontinental in 2011, was closed in September 2014.

Name: L’Impact de Drummondville
What happened?: L’Impact de Drummondville, a Transcontinental community newspaper, was closed in September, 2014.

Name: Roussillon Express
What happened?: Roussillon Express, a TC publication, was closed in September, 2014 due to the TC-QMI deal. It competed with Quebecor’s Le Reflet in Delson.

Name: Pub Extra Magazine
What happened?: Néomédia bought Pub Extra Magazine and publish it online only; a result of the Transcontinental/Quebcor merger.

Name: Le Journal de Magog
What happened?: Le Journal de Magog, a Transcontinental publication, was closed in September, 2014.

Name: La Voix de la Matanie
What happened?: La Voix de la Matanie, a Transcontinental community newspaper, was closed September, 2014.

Name: La Voix Gaspésienne
What happened?: La Voix Gaspésienne, a Transcontinental community newspaper, was closed September, 2014.

Name: L’Echo de la Lièvre
What happened?: L’Echo de la Lièvre, a Transcontinental community newspaper, was closed September, 2014.

Name: Point de vue Laurentides
What happened?: Point de vue Laurentides, a Transcontinental community newspaper, was closed September, 2014.

Name: L’Écho de Repentigny
What happened?: L’Écho de Repentigny, a Transcontinental community newspaper, was closed September, 2014.

Name: Le Progrès Écho
What happened?: Le Progrès Écho, a Transcontinental community newspaper, was closed September, 2014.

Name: Le Rimouskois
What happened?: Le Rimouskois, a Transcontinental community newspaper, was closed September, 2014.

Name: Abitibi Express – Rouyn-Noranda
What happened?: Abitibi Express – Rouyn-Noranda, a Transcontinental community newspaper, was closed September, 2014. Competed with Quebecor’s Le Citoyen. A casualty of the TC-QMI deal.

Name: L’Écho de Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu
What happened?: L’Écho de Saint-Jean-sur-Richelieu, a Transcontinental community newspaper, was closed September, 2014.

Name: Le Riverain
What happened?: Le Riverain, a Transcontinental community newspaper, was closed September, 2014.

Name: Édition Beauce Nord
What happened?: Édition Beauce Nord, a Transcontinental community newspaper, closed in September, 2014.

Name: L’Écho de Shawinigan
What happened?: L’Écho de Shawinigan, a Transcontinental community newspaper, was closed September, 2014.

Name: Sorel-Tracy Express
What happened?: Néomédia bought the community newspaper the Sorel-Tracy Express, and publish them online only as of September, 2014.

Name: Abitibi Express – Val d’Or
What happened?: Abitibi Express – Val d’Or, a Transcontinental community newspaper, was closed September, 2014.

Name: Valleyfield Express
What happened?: Valleyfield Express, a Transcontinental community newspaper, was closed September, 2014. TC Media originally launched the weekly print (and online) publication, the Valleyfield Express.ca, in 2012.

Name: Chambly Express
What happened?: Chambly Express, a community newspaper, was purchased by Néomédia in September 2014 and is now published online only.

Name: Le Journal de Joliette
What happened?: Le Journal de Joliette, a community newspaper, was purchased by Néomédia in September 2014 and are now published online only.

Name: L'Écho de Laval
What happened?: L'Écho de Laval, a community newspaper, was purchased by Néomédia in September 2014 and are now published online only.

Name: Vallée-du-Richelieu Express
What happened?: Vallée-du-Richelieu Express, a community newspaper, was purchased by Néomédia in September 2014 and are now published online only.

Name: Le Réveil
What happened?: Le Réveil, a community newspaper, was purchased by Néomédia in September 2014 and are now published online only.

Name: Le Point du Lac-Saint-Jean
What happened?: Le Point du Lac-Saint-Jean, a community newspaper, was purchased by Néomédia in September 2014 and is now published online only.

Name: L'Écho de la Rive-Nord
What happened?: L'Écho de la Rive-Nord, a community newspaper, was purchased by Néomédia in September 2014 and are now published online only.

Name: L'Écho de Trois-Rivières
What happened?: L'Écho de Trois-Rivières, a community newspaper, was purchased by Néomédia in September 2014 and are now published online only.

Name: Agri-Vallée
What happened?: Agri-Vallée, a community newspaper, was purchased by Néomédia in September 2014 and are now published online only.

Name: Le Saint-Laurent Portage
What happened?: Le Saint-Laurent Portage, a Transcontinental community newspaper, was closed September, 2014.

Name: East Gwillimbury Express
What happened?: Metroland  launched the East Gwillimbury Express on September 11, 2014.

Name: Kelowna Capital News
What happened?: The Black Press-owned Kelowna Capital News was a daily newspaper until 2011 when it began publishing three times a week. As of Sept. 15, 2014, it began appearing twice per week.

Name: Valley Now
What happened?: TC Media launched a new community newspaper in Nova Scotia on November 12. Valley Now is a free weekly publication serving the residents of Kings, Annapolis and Hants counties.

Name: Channel 6
What happened?: Channel 6, a new online local news outlet, was launched May 29, 2015.

Name: Metro online - Hamilton
What happened?: Metro Canada announced in April 2012 that it would open a digital-only news edition in Hamilton. It closed on December 9, 2014.

Name: Metro online - Kitchener
What happened?: Metro Canada announced in April 2012 that it would open a digital-only news edition in Kitchener. It closed on December 9, 2014.

Name: Metro online - Victoria
What happened?: Metro Canada announced in April 2012 that it would open a digital-only news edition in Victoria. It closed on December 9, 2014.

Name: Metro online - Windsor
What happened?: Metro Canada announced in April 2012 that it would open a digital-only news edition in Windsor. It closed on December 9, 2014.

Name: South Cowichan Echo
What happened?: A new monthly community newspaper, the South Cowichan Echo, opened in December, 2014.

Name: kamloopsbcnow.com
What happened?: This online local news site in Kamloops is owned by the same company that publishes KelownaNow.com. Its published its first tweet in January, 2015.

Name: Xtra - Ottawa
What happened?: Xtra - Ottawa ended its print publication in February, 2015 and now appears online only.

Name: Xtra - Vancouver
What happened?: Xtra - Vancouver ended its print publication in February, 2015 and now appears online only.

Name: Xtra - Toronto
What happened?: Xtra - Toronto ended its print publication in February, 2015 and now appears online only.

Name: Cowichan Valley News Leader Pictorial
What happened?: The Black Press publication, the Cowichan Valley News Leader Pictoral, switched from daily to weekly publication in  March, 2013 before finally closing entirely in March 2015.

Name: Fast Forward Weekly
What happened?: Fast Forward Weekly first transitioned to an online news source and then closed March, 2015.

Name: Oceanside Star
What happened?: Purchased from Glacier Media, the Oceanside Star was closed by Black Press in March, 2015.

Name: Campbell River Courier-Islander
What happened?: Purchased from Glacier Media, the Campbell River Courier-Islander was closed by Black Press in March, 2015.

Name: Harbour City Star
What happened?: Purchased from Glacier Media, the Harbour City Star community paper was closed in April, 2015 by Black Press.

Name: Global News
What happened?: Global News' local Montreal newscast began broadcasting from Toronto as of April 2015.

Name: Niagara This Week
What happened?: Previously published twice a week, Niagara This Week began publishing weekly as of May 2015.

Name: Prince George Free Press
What happened?: The Prince George Free Press, owned by Aberdeen publishing, closed in May 2015.

Name: Breakfast Television
What happened?: Rogers cancelled its Breakfast Television show in Edmonton in May 2015.

Name: Omni
What happened?: OMNI Television, the multicultural broadcast wing of Rogers Media Inc., shut down its Punjabi, Mandarin, Cantonese and Italian newscasts in May 2015. The newscasts were replaced by current affairs shows in Cantonese, Mandarin and Punjabi that spend more time on each story but do not include original reporting. The Italian newscast was scrapped entirely and replaced with an Italian-language soap opera.

Name: VancouverDesi.com
What happened?: In the fall of 2012, the Vancouver Province launched a new website targeted at the South Asian community in B.C.: VancouverDesi.com. It closed in June of 2015, and the url now redirects to the Province's Asia Pacific section.

Name: The Meadow Lake Progress
What happened?: In July 2013 Sun Media announced the closure of The Meadow Lake Progress, a weekly publication.

Name: Loyalist City Newschasers
What happened?: The Loyalist City Newschasers is a local private Facebook group that publishes news. It started in December, 2013.

Name: The Cult
What happened?: Cult MTL is a daily web and monthly print publication focusing on local culture, founded in July 2012 and run by former employees of the Mirror.

Name: Voir
What happened?: Voir is a community paper that reduced its publication schedule from weekly to every two weeks in May 2013.

Name: Hour
What happened?: The Hour, a commuity newspaper in Montreal, closed in May 2012.

Name: ICI
What happened?: The Montreal community newspaper ICI closed in April 2009.

Name: La Ronge Northerner
What happened?: La Ronge Northerner, a Glacier Media title, ceased publication in August 2015.

Name: Hudson Bay Post Review
What happened?: Hudson Bay Post Review, a Glacier Media title, ceased publication in August 2015.

Name: The Mainlander
What happened?: The Mainlander is a news and views website that bills itself as "Vancouver's Place for Progressive Politics", opened in November 2010.

Name: The Telegram
What happened?: The Sunday edition of The Telegram, a Transcontinental paper based in St. John's, was cancelled as of  September 21st, 2008.

Name: The Brockville Recorder and Times
What happened?: The Brockville Recorder and Times, owned by Sun Media, cancelled its Monday edition in 2009.

Name: Victoria Times Colonist
What happened?: Canwest's Victoria Times Colonist reduced its publishing cycle to 6 days,Tues-Sunday, in June 2009.

Name: The Gazette
What happened?: The Montreal Gazette, a Postmedia paid-circulation daily paper, stopped publishing a Sunday edition in August 2008.

Name: La Presse
What happened?: La Presse, a daily paid paper owned by Power Corp. of Canada, stopped publishing a Sunday edition in June 2009.

Name: St.Thomas Times-Journal
What happened?: Sun Media's St. Thomas Times-Journal stopped publishing on Mondays as of  December 22, 2008.

Name: Pembroke Daily Observer
What happened?: The Sun Media-owned Pembroke Daily Observer stopped publishing a Monday edition in 2008.

Name: Montreal News at Noon
What happened?: Global's News at Noon is a new half-hour local newscast produced out of Montreal and hosted by Jamie Orchard. It launched August 17, 2015.

Name: Northern Sun News
What happened?: The September 2, 2015 issue was the final edition of The Northern Sun News, a community paper.

Name: Ottawa XPress
What happened?: The XPress, owned by Voir Communications, closed down in May 2012.

Name: Roundhouse Radio
What happened?: A new hyper-local private radio station called Roundhouse Radio launched in September 2015.

Name: Campbell River/Comox Valley Daily
What happened?: Campbell River/Comox Valley Daily, created in 2011 by Black Press, ceased publishing in December 2013.

Name: Fraser Valley Daily
What happened?: The Fraser Valley Daily,  a free newspaper that covered Chilliwack and Abbotsford, ceased publication in 2013.

Name: Dawson Creek Daily News
What happened?: In early 2014 Glacier media merged two daily newspapers in the Peace River region of British Columbia: the Dawson Creek Daily News and the Alaska Highway News in Fort St. John. The company said the Alaska Highway News would expand to cover Dawson Creek, Fort Nelson to the north and the surrounding areas.

Name: Golden Ears Daily
What happened?: The Golden Ears Daily, a Black Press-owned free daily, ceased publication in November, 2013.

Name: Cramahe Now
What happened?: Cramahe Now is a hyperlocal news site, launched in March 2009.

Name: Northumberland Today
What happened?: In March 2009, Quebecor's Port Hope Guide merged with the Cobourg Daily Star and the Colborne Chronicle, a community paper, to create Northumberland Today.

Name: Wainwright Star
What happened?: The Wainrwright Star and the Wainwright Edge merged to create the Wainright Star/Edge, effective Nov. 1, 2013. The new community paper appears on Fridays.

Name: The Cariboo Advisor
What happened?: Black Press-owned The Cariboo Adviser, the Williams Lake Tribune and its weekend edition, Tribune Weekend, merged on Sept. 4, 2013. They were replaced by the free community paper, the Williams Lake Tribune, distributed on Wednesdays and the Weekend Advisor, published on Fridays.

Name: Williams Lake Tribune & the Weekend Advisor edition
What happened?: Black Press-owned The Cariboo Adviser, the Williams Lake Tribune and its weekend edition, Tribune Weekend, merged on Sept. 4, 2013. They were replaced by the free community paper, the Williams Lake Tribune, distributed on Wednesdays and the Weekend Advisor, published on Fridays.

Name: The Lunenburg County Progress Bulletin
What happened?: The Lunenburg County Progress Bulletin was created through the merger of the Bridgewater Bulletin (est. 1887) and Lunenburg Progress Enterprise (est. 1876) in May 2011. The new publication is a locally owned independent newspaper published every Wednesday by Lighthouse Media Group.
